trial_identification.studytitle: Preventing the development of panic disorder in vulnerable patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Psychological and physiological correlates of panic disorder in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and efficacy of prevention of panic anxiety using cognitive behaviour therapy

interventions.interventions: 20 patients with COPD receive a one hour session of cognitive behaviour therapy per week for four weeks - this is the intervention. All continue to receive active treatment as usual for their COPD. All subjects are then assessed every six months over an 18 month follow-up period.
interventions.comparator: 20 control patients with COPD don't receive this intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The effectiveness of the brief, standardised CBT intervention in decreasing the likelihood that patients will develop symptoms of panic disorder
primaryOutcome.timepoint: An assessment session every six months over 18 month follow-up period.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To reduce the personal and economic burder associated with the development of panic disorder in COPD patients.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: An assessment session every six months over 18 month follow-up period.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of COPD, with no age limits on enrolment.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Lack of written fluency in EnglishA co-existing severe disease and/or mental illness.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Nicole Livermore (enrolled in part-time PhD degree at University of Sydney

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Dr. Louise Sharpe, School of Psychology, University of Sydney, (N. Livermore's primary supervisor)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: 40 patients with COPD are randomly allocated to either receive a four session preventative CBT intervention, or not receive this intervention in addition to usual treatment. Subjects are then followed up every six months for 18 months to investigate the efficacy of the intervention in preventing the development/worsening of panic anxiety symptoms.
